entry.title: Agenda : SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2025 2nd Edition
entry.content:
3 Tracks

3 Panel Discussion 

20 Speakers 

There will be 3 tracks 

Venue :  CMR Institute of Technology 

https://maps.app.goo.gl/cFr44eqzPskFUxzg8

1. Analytics Track

Located in the Central Auditorium, this track covers analytics and data. The agenda includes a panel discussion on S/4HANA & AI synergy, and a session on the Open Era of SAP Analytics. Attendees will also learn about reskilling for S/4HANA and Embedded Analytics, as well as AI-driven analytics and the integration of S4HANA + DataSphere.

2. AI Track

This track, held in Seminar Hall 153, focuses on artificial intelligence within the SAP ecosystem. Topics include an introduction to AI in SAP, automated controls, and Generative AI for SAP GRC. The afternoon sessions cover transforming SAP with AI agents and intelligent enterprise, followed by a discussion on AI-driven SAP auditing.

 

3. S/4HANA Track

This track, in Seminar Hall 159, is dedicated to SAP S/4HANA. Sessions cover predictions for intelligent enterprises, unifying the cloud with SAP BTP, and building modern apps with RAP and CAP. A panel discussion on the future of autonomous agents and a session on ERP Copilots are also featured.

entry.title: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
As valued members of our Community, we’d like to share upcoming changes to SAP Universal ID (UID). It is important that you have all the details to make the transition as simple as possible.

SAP is updating its SAP Universal ID framework to simplify user experiences and improve security. The key change is that the UID will no longer serve as an identity provider, meaning it will no longer represent a digital gatekeeper that checks if the person logging in is really who they say they are. Moving forward, users will have to use their email address specific to the user ID, or the specific/individual user ID (S-/P-user). Please note that the SAP Universal ID will still be used as a wallet to collect and store user identities, community reputation and learning certificates.

The information below provides you with a view into the current state of SAP Universal ID, the upcoming changes, benefits of this evolution, and the impact on you.  

If you have any issues during the migration and this article doesn’t address them, our SAP support can help.

What is SAP Universal ID?

SAP Universal ID (UID) was created to serve as a unified personal account or wallet across all SAP systems, managing and linking various user identities such as S-/P-users. This consolidation ensured that learning certificates, awards, and community reputation are retained lifelong, regardless of organizational changes.

What´s changing and what does this mean to you?

As mentioned above, SAP Universal ID will no longer serve as an identity provider. Instead, users will be authenticated through the SAP standard authentication mechanism (SAP IAS).

This change in the authentication approach requires a user password migration for all users of SAP Universal ID. For most users, those with only one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID, the password migration will happen automatically. No action is required from those users. They will continue to log in using their email address and the password they are accustomed to.

Users with more than one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID will be guided through a step-by-step process to set new password or confirm existing passwords. This will occur during the migration period, that takes place from August 25th till September 29th, 2025.

The SAP Universal ID account will remain active, allowing users to keep linking and managing their user identities in the SAP UID Account Manager. Another benefit of the UID Password Migration initiative for end users is that they lay the foundation for the future introduction of 'Remember me' functionality. Although the enablement timeline cannot be confirmed at this stage, technical preparations are underway, and we will communicate once the feature becomes available.

From September 29th, users will login with their e-mail address or user identity with the associated password. Single sign-on with SAP Universal ID will not be possible anymore. Users who haven’t gone through the password migration procedure during the mentioned period, will need to log in with any of their S-/P-user ID (or the email address associated to it) and a respective password, that was initially set during user creation. In case the password is forgotten, the “forgot password” link can be used for reset. Passwords for the remaining users can be subsequently reset once logged in to the SAP Account Manager.

Why Is SAP Making This Change? 

This change is part of SAP’s broader identity renovation strategy. As SAP continues to evolve its identity and user management solutions, the transition to identity renovation represents a new chapter in digital identity consolidation and management. While SAP Universal ID remains a pivotal part of this strategy, the shift towards SAP IAS sessions highlights the dynamic nature of enterprise technology. For customers and partners understanding and adapting to these changes will ensure optimized digital interactions within the SAP ecosystem. 

You can learn more about it in the Bring Your Own Identity: SAP's Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management blog post.

Detailed User Guide

This guide shows the single steps, you will be asked to go through to set or confirm your passwords during the UID password migration. Please note, that these steps will be required only from users with more than one user identity (S/P-user) linked in their SAP Universal ID. If you belong to the majority users, that have only one user identity (just one either S- or P-user) linked to their UID, the migration will happen automatically in the background and no action will be needed from you.

1. Once you log in, we will ask you to set new passwords to the user identities, that are linked in your SAP Universal ID. You have also the option to choose “remind me later”. In that case, we will ask you again the next time you log in. Please keep in mind, that you should fulfill these steps until September 29th.

2. In the next screen, you will see all your linked user identities. You can either keep and confirm current password, choose to use the UID password or set a completely new password. You need to choose one of the options for each linked user identity. Once done, click on “confirm”.

3. To confirm your choices, we will ask you for your current SAP Universal ID password:

4. You will see a summary of your choices, once you confirmed with your UID password:

After setting successfully your passwords, you will be able to log in with your e-mail address or S-/P-user ID with the associated password.

Further Resources

Read our News article to know more about SAP’s Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management.  If you have any issues during the migration and this article didn’t address them, our SAP support can help.

entry.title: Outbound Transportation from MFG site having EWM,StRM, Lean Warehouse under one Freight Order to DC
entry.content:
Many Industries consider the manufacturing location as a plant in SAP. Under the plant, many storage locations would be available in SAP and some of them would be either IM managed (or Lean Warehouse managed), or Stock Room Managed (StRM) or EWM managed. As a part of the distribution process from the manufacturing site, there would be every chance that the different products from all these types of warehouses need to be shipped to other DC site or to the customer.

This blog covers my personal insights about the outbound process in SAP from MFG (manufacturing) site to other DC (distribution center) or to the customer wherein the different products are picked up from Lean Warehouse, StRM and EWM managed warehouse locations and loaded onto the the same vehicle under the single Freight Order (FO) with the help of SAP EWM and SAP TM ASR integration in basic S/4 HANA licence or in advanced S/4 HANA license using S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 version. 

Process FLow - 

Process Flow - MFG Site (that has LE, StRM and EWM warehouse) to another DC / Customer in single Freight Order

Master Data -

  1. Maintain Loading Point location for EWM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - EWM Warehouse

 2. Maintain Loading Point location for StRM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - StRM Warehouse

3. Maintain Loading Point location for LE specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - LE Warehouse

4. Assign EWM Door in EWM Warehouse to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCWM/DOOR_SCU -

Assign EWM Door to Loading Point

5. Assign StRM and LE Warehouse specific Door to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCMTMS/M_ASRDOOR -

Assign StRM and LE Door to Loading Point

Documents in S/4 HANA -

1. Create multiple STO's from MFG plant to another DC.

2. Create multiple OBD's - 

EWM Relevant Delivery

Next -

StRM Relevant Delivery

Next -

Lean WH Relevant Delivery

3. Freight Unit (FU) gets created automatically and is further planned with the help of transportation cockpit automatically / manually and Freight Order (FO) is created and carrier is assigned based on the existing freight agreement arrangements.

Planning of Multiple Freight Units that have warehouse specific Loading Points

4. Perform each warehouse specific steps - picking, packing and staging.

5. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of LE Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

Update in FO Execution Status after shipping steps in LE Warehouse

6. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of StRM Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Execution after Shipping steps in StRM Warehouse

7.Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of EWMM Warehouse - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Status Overview at EWM Loading Point

Next -

FO Execution after Shipping steps in EWM Warehouse

Please share your comment and/or feedback in case of any suggestions.
Happy Reading !!!
Thanks
Prashant

Note -  The concept of usage of "Consignment Order" in ASR during the outbound process shipment for multiple customers will be covered in next blog.
Please follow topic to know more about SAP Extended Warehouse Management.
Please post and answer questions at here
Please read other posts on the topic at here

entry.title: New Features: Dark Mode (Beta) and Events Listings
entry.content:
I’m back to report a couple new improvements to SAP Community – one that makes it more convenient to find events that interest you, and another that addresses a popular accessibility request from our feedback list.

Consolidation of Events

A community goes beyond a website. It also includes events – both online and in-person – that allow people to come together to learn and connect.

If you’re a community member who enjoys webinars, SAP CodeJam sessions, meet-ups, and more, then you know that you’ve previously needed to comb through various sections to find events that appeal to you…especially in your area. There’s a general Events page, but there are also (as an example) events available through location groups. You couldn’t go to a single place on SAP Community to find every upcoming event.

Until now.

In the past, the “View all Events” option, accessible from the “Events” pulldown menu, only offered filtering for event types (e.g., Devtoberfest, SAP CodeJam), event status (e.g., in progress, upcoming), and labels (e.g., physical, online). If you wanted to find other specific meetups and events convenient for you, you had to visit the location groups within your vicinity. Thanks to improvements rolled out today, however, the View all Events page now truly shows all events, including those hosted by location groups.

We’ve expanded the Events page with filtering options for countries, making it easier for you to find even more educational and social activities close to you by pulling details from the location groups. We’ve also added a filter for SAP Managed Tags that allows you to get very specific when searching for events that match your interests.

As an example, as an American, I’d love to get together with other community members at an in-person event happening near me. So for my search of events, I selected United States (for the country), SAP Community (as the tag), physical (as a label), and upcoming (as the event status) – and, lucky me, looks like I found a cool get-together right by my office at SAP’s American headquarters in Newtown Square, Pennsylvania! (OK, that’s a made-up event from our test site, but I sure would love to participate if it were real – especially if that dog is attending, too.)

If you’d rather not refine your search with that level of granularity, you can make multiple selections from every filter. Get as focused, or as broad, as you want. Switch between list and calendar displays while you’re at it. Play around with the various options, and we hope to see you at an event very soon!

Introducing Dark Mode (Beta)

You asked for it.

You got it.

Mostly.

Our platform now offers a dark-mode option, but it’s in a beta phase – meaning we’re still working on features and working out some issues.

More on those in a bit. First, I want to explain how to turn dark mode on.

After logging in (log-in is required), open the pulldown menu from the person icon in the upper right, then select “Switch to Dark Mode (BETA)”:

You’ll immediately see the site in dark mode, although some elements of the site, such as headers and menus, remain in light mode.

As we refine this option during the beta phase, we’ll apply dark mode to all parts of the site. Also, we’ll fix an issue with replies in discussions, events, and direct messages. At the moment, the text in these replies is too dark to see easily.

We’re aware of the problem, and we should have it resolved before the end of the week.

Beyond those minor items, the beta is up and available for you to try out. Switch dark mode on and see what you think.

Don’t like it? Just go back to the pulldown and select “Switch to Light Mode” to return to the platform’s default look and feel.

Experiment to see which experience works best for you, and remember that we’ll continue to make refinements to dark mode during the beta phase.

entry.title: Rethinking Clean Core in SAP: From Rigid Formalism to Pragmatic Common Sense
entry.content:
When the Clean Core concept first entered the SAP market, it was often interpreted in an excessively pragmatic and, at times, unreasonable way by consultants and companies. What followed was a period of confusion: architects and developers applied Clean Core with an overly formalistic mindset—focusing on the letter of the law rather than the spirit of the law, and overlooking the real context, the current state of systems, and urgent regulatory requirements.

As a result, some projects overspent on complex, costly, and low-impact initiatives. Take, for example:

  • The upcoming new tax framework in Brazil and how it will be implemented,
  • The rollout of PIX automatic payments,
  • Or the Brazilian Nota Fiscal integration with SAP DRC.

These are urgent, business-critical needs where rigid interpretations of Clean Core would not be feasible.

That’s why SAP’s new and more flexible interpretation of Clean Core is so welcome. It adapts to today’s enterprise realities—whether modernizing ECC systems into S/4HANA, or addressing urgent legal compliance requirements—while keeping the principle of a maintainable, innovation-ready core intact. In the end, common sense must prevail.

Clean Core: Modernizing SAP S/4HANA Cloud with Safe, Flexible Extensibility

The Clean Core approach is SAP’s strategic vision to ensure that SAP S/4HANA Cloud systems remain up-to-date, innovation-ready, and cost-effective—without compromising upgradeability or system stability.

The Essence of “Clean Core”

  • Core: critical elements—business processes, master and transactional data, integrations, operations, and extensibility.
  • Clean: current, transparent, unmodified, consistent, and cloud-compliant.
  • A Clean Core system balances standardization with tailored innovation, reducing TCO and preserving agility.

Clean Core Extensibility: The Four Levels SAP has evolved from a binary model into a nuanced Clean Core Level Concept:

  • Level A – Ideal: compliant extensions via ABAP Cloud or SAP BTP (public APIs only).
  • Level B – Acceptable: classic, documented APIs with reasonable upgrade safety.
  • Level C – Partial: reliance on internal objects or older approaches—higher risk.
  • Level D – Not Recommended: unsupported modifications, direct table writes, or noAPI objects, creating technical debt.

This framework allows companies to assess risk, remediate step by step, and prioritize modernization—especially targeting Level D practices.

The Value

  • Upgrade stability
  • Transparent risk assessment
  • Faster innovation cycles
  • Reduced technical debt
  • Pragmatic modernization for business and legal needs

Clean Core is not about forbidding customizations—it’s about responsible extensibility. With SAP’s updated guidance, organizations can extend where it makes sense, respect compliance requirements, and still keep their ERP cores clean, stable, and future-ready.

#SAP #S4HANACloud #CleanCore #Extensibility #CloudTransformation

entry.title: White Space, Begone! New Pilot Removes Widgets Column from Blog Posts
entry.content:
For as long as I can remember, even going back to the previous SAP Community platform, members have asked us to reduce the amount of white space on post pages, arguing that the layout makes readability more difficult. It’s a complaint that continues today – and one that we’re taking steps to address.

The current platform includes a column for widgets (e.g., Top Kudoed Authors), but, depending on the length of a blog post, that column might be mostly blank. For that reason, members have requested its removal, and we’re now testing the favorability of that approach.

To help illustrate the point, here’s a blog post with the widgets column:

Now here’s the very same post with the widgets column (and white space) removed:

What do you think? Better? Worse? Don’t care one way or the other? We’re running a four-week pilot (starting today) so you can let us know!

To experience a blog board free of the widgets column (and the white space that comes with), head on over to the Application Development and Automation group. We’re currently testing that look and feel over there to give members the opportunity to view blog posts without the widgets.

(Note: We are aware of issues with the formatting of some posts now that we've removed the widgets column. If this change affected the placement of images in your post, for example, you'll need to edit to correct. Per the "Blog Formatting Post-Migration" section of this post, it's best to use the blog tool as intended, making sure to avoid complicated html and to clear formatting when copying over text.)  

Compare the blog posts in the Application Development and Automation group to blog posts in other areas on the community. If you prefer the new widget-less layout, let us know in the comments below. Or, if you favor blog posts with widgets and the white space, make sure to share your opinions in the comments as well. We’ll review all feedback received between today (Tuesday, August 26) and Tuesday, September 23, then determine which layout members seem to favor.

If enough members choose the new approach (with the widgets and space gone), we can update all blog boards to match what you see in the Application Development and Automation group. Then again, if members tell us to leave the current layout alone, that’s what we’ll do (and we’ll switch the Application Development and Automation posts back to match the other boards).

Will we change the status of this feedback item to “Delivered”? Or “Declined”? You can help us decide!

With this pilot, we’re inviting members to provide feedback that will help influence the design of our site – as it should be in a community that belongs to all of us.

We look forward to reading your input below!

entry.title: SAP Translation Hub
entry.content:
Хочете подолати мовні бар'єри та розкрити весь потенціал SAP рідною мовою?

Зареєструйтеся на пізнавальний вебінар, розроблений для революційних змін у вашому підході до перекладу документів та програмного забезпечення.

Приєднуйтесь до нашої панелі експертів, які розкриють трансформаційні можливості Translation Hub із захопливою демонстрацією практичного застосування в реальному часі, щоб проілюструвати його практичний вплив. Готуйтеся надихнутися!

🇺🇦Цікавий факт: українська мова підтримується в інтерфейсі рішень SAP уже майже 20 років, а досвід використання рішень SAP українськими компаніями — 30 років!

За цей час сформовано потужну базу термінології та перекладацьких даних, що дозволяє максимально ефективно використовувати SAP Translation Hub і забезпечувати високу якість перекладу українською.

Радимо ознайомитися з можливостями сервісу та протестувати їх на власних матеріалах.

entry.title: Event Summary: SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2025 (2nd Edition)
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2025 (2nd Edition) was a full-day event packed with technical sessions and strategic insights from various  speakers. The event's content provided a comprehensive look at the latest advancements in SAP, with a strong emphasis on the intersection of S/4HANA, AI, and Analytics.

Event Highlights & Lowlights

Highlights:

  • 900 Registrations: The event saw a massive number of registrations, indicating strong interest and engagement from the SAP community.
  • 10 Speakers: A total of 10 speakers shared their knowledge and insights on various SAP related topics, providing a wide range of expertise.
  • MOURI Tech Stall: MOURI Tech had a prominent stall at the event, which served as a key point for networking and interaction.

Lowlights:

  • 25% Turnaround: Despite the high number of registrations, the event had a 25% turnaround, which indicates a significant number of registered attendees did not show up.
  • Event T-Shirt Arrived After the Event: A notable logistical issue was that the event T-shirts were not available for attendees on the day of the event

The Event started with the panel discussion:

FROM TRANSACTIONAL TO PREDICTIVE: THE S/4HANA AND AI SYNERGY

  • DR. MAHESH KUMAR CV Founding Member, Global Agentic AI Consortium
  • GUPTA KANDULA AVP, HCLTech
  • RASHMI JOSHI Technical Solution Architect, IBM
  • SUNIL KUMAR NAVYA Senior Director, MOURI Tech

 This high-level panel, a key highlight of the event, delved into how S/4HANA's transactional data and AI/ML capabilities combine to deliver predictive analytics. The discussion emphasized the shift from merely reporting on past events to anticipating future outcomes.

  • Immanuel Kolagani (MOURI Tech): The Open Era of SAP Analytics - Datasphere and BDC :Immanuel's session focused on SAP Datasphere and the Business Data Catalog (BDC). He explained how these tools represent SAP's commitment to an open data strategy, allowing for seamless integration and management of data from various sources to enable a unified analytics landscape.
  • Srinivas Reddy Edulakanti (Patil Group): SAP Transformation Journey Challenges :  This talk provided a candid look at the real-world challenges organizations face during their SAP transformation projects. Srinivas shared insights on overcoming common hurdles, from technical complexities to change management issues, offering practical advice for a smoother journey.
  • Dr. Mahesh Kumar CV (Al Bharath Consortium): How to Reskill in the age of S4HANA, Embedded Analytics, AI...SAP BDC :  Dr. Kumar's session was a crucial guide for professionals looking to stay relevant in the rapidly evolving SAP landscape. He outlined the key skills needed for the future, emphasizing the importance of expertise in S/4HANA, embedded analytics, AI, and SAP BTP.
  • Naga Prathima Mummidisetti (MOURI Tech): Unifying the Cloud: Harnessing SAP BTP Integration Suite for a Connected Enterprise : This talk provided a deep dive into the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), specifically focusing on its Integration Suite. Naga Prathima explained how organizations can use BTP to seamlessly connect disparate systems, both SAP and non-SAP, to create a cohesive and data-rich landscape essential for modern business operations.
  • Vidya Sagar Yedla (MOURI Tech): Building Modern Apps with RAP and CAP: A Developer's Journey Aimed at developers, this session was a practical guide to building modern, cloud-native applications on SAP BTP. Vidya Sagar demonstrated the use of the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) and the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) to create flexible and scalable applications that extend the functionality of S/4HANA.
  • Hitendra Munjampally (MOURI Tech): Rise of ERP Copilots: AI Assistants Transforming Enterprise Productivity :  Hitendra's session explored the growing trend of AI copilots within ERP systems. He demonstrated how tools like SAP Joule can act as intelligent assistants, streamlining workflows, automating routine tasks, and providing users with actionable insights directly within their SAP interface.
  • Madhavi Arelli (SRIA Infotech): SAP AI in Transform Business with AI Agents, and Smarter Models : Madhavi’s session provided a broad overview of how AI and intelligent models can fundamentally transform business processes. She presented various case studies demonstrating how AI agents can optimize operations, improve decision-making, and create new business models.
  • Vinod Kumar Reddy Komma (MOURI Tech): AI-Powered SAP: Where to Begin and What to Expec: Vinod's talk served as a guide for organizations new to integrating AI with SAP. He outlined the starting points, necessary prerequisites, and a realistic roadmap for adopting AI, setting expectations for the benefits and challenges of the journey.
  • Mrinalini KR (ToggleNow): From Reactive to Predictive: AI-Driven SAP Auditing : Mrinalini's talk addressed the evolution of auditing within the SAP environment. She demonstrated how AI can move auditing from a reactive, post-event process to a predictive one, using machine learning to identify anomalies and potential fraud risks in real-time.
  • Sudhakar Nagadevara (MOURI Tech): Beyond Development: Business AI + Joule Driving the Intelligent Enterprise:  This session shifted the focus from technical development to the business impact of AI. Sudhakar explored how the combination of business AI applications and SAP's AI copilot, Joule, enables users at all levels to become more productive and contributes to the overall intelligent enterprise strategy.
  • Subbu Sravan Mulumudi (ToggleNow): Gen AI Agents for SAP GRC ; Summary: A specialized topic, this session highlighted the use of Generative AI agents to enhance SAP Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC). Subbu Sravan showcased how these agents can assist in creating and managing compliance rules, simulating risk scenarios, and improving audit readiness.

Finally event ended with the group photo.

entry.title: Thumbs Up for the New “Kudos Received” Progression Badges!
entry.content:
The members have spoken. The relaunch of our progression badge sets is a hit!

We started last week by rolling out four new badges that reward members for providing solutions to questions. Response to my announcement in What’s New has been extremely positive.  “Bringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!” has thousands of views and dozens of kudos. Good thing for me, because the next progression set celebrates members for the number of kudos they received – so all those recent kudos sure will come in handy toward my progress!

Whether you call them a thumbs-up (as they appear in the site design), a like (as they were known in the previous SAP Community platform), or a kudo (as they’re called in our current platform), you know that your content has found an audience when members take the time to click that lovely little icon to show their appreciation for your contribution. And we know you’re the kind of member who deserves special gamification rewards!

As with the “solutions” badge set, this new set will have five badges in total, although the first badge has been available since the launch of our latest community platform last year. We’ve added four more badges to this set, and you progress based on the number of kudos received. Per the image below, the second badge requires 50 kudos, the third requires 100, the fourth requires 200, and the fifth requires 500.

We’ll launch these badges at some point tomorrow, Thursday, August 28, one at a time over a period of a few hours. Depending on how many kudos you’ve received, don’t be surprised if you get multiple notifications as the badge assignment occurs during this period. (If you’re still waiting by Friday, August 29, try logging out and in again. Any new badges should show up then.)

Once again, we’ll award these badges retroactively. Any numbers migrated from the previous platform to this one count toward your progress, and kudos for any content type (e.g., blog post, comment) count as well. So if you’ve been contributing popular content for years, you may have done enough to earn all five badges.

Wondering if you’re already part of the “500+ kudos received” club? You can check for yourself in your “My content” area. In my last post, I provided instructions about how to find your content, but here’s a reminder for your convenience.

First, make sure you’ve logged in. Click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page. Select “My content” from the dropdown.

“Kudos received” appears in the gray box at the very top. To help illustrate, I’m once again relying on the anonymous member who appeared in last week’s post, by sharing a screenshot from his “My content” page. (He didn’t complain then, so I hope he doesn’t mind now. Or maybe he just hasn’t noticed yet.)

Looks like this community veteran has received thousands of kudos over the years – more than enough to rack up all four badges tomorrow.

How about you? If you’re expecting all four of the new badges tomorrow, then kudos to you! (Pun intended.) Whether you receive one, five, or any number in between, we appreciate your involvement in SAP Community. More importantly, our members appreciate your activity – evidenced by all their kudos for you!

If you don’t get a badge (or get one or some but want them all), you’ll have plenty of opportunity in future to complete the set. All you need to do is continue to contribute quality content to SAP Community. If members like what you’re sharing, you can eventually accrue enough kudos to work your way through this new progression set.

Not the kind of member who likes to publish content? That’s OK. We have more progression badge sets coming in the weeks ahead, and not all of them depend on posting to SAP Community. There are lots of things members can do to create a positive community, and we’ll be awarding badges for those, too.

Look for updates here in the What’s New section to learn how you can receive gamification rewards as we introduce new progression sets. One thing is certain: The more you do in SAP Community, the more badges you can earn. My advice if you’re a badge hunter? Stay active. Stay engaged. In short, stay an important part of SAP Community. We look forward to recognizing all members who make our community a better place!

entry.title: SAP Developer News August 28th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST:  https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/08/28/sap-developer-news-august-28th-2025/

SAP BTP ABAP Environment, release 2508 

  • Blog Post: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-btp-abap-environment-release-2508/ba-p/14182635 

 

SAP Open Source Webinar on Gardener 

  • SAP Open Source Webinars https://events.sap.com/ospo-webinar-series/en_us/home.html  
  • Webinar registration https://events.sap.com/neutral-governance-for-gardener-project/en_us/registration.html  
  • Gardener project https://github.com/gardener/gardener  

 

Garden Update - SAP Community   

  • Blog Post: https://community.sap.com/t5/coffee-corner-discussions/garden-update-the-raised-bed-went-wild/td-p/14194744 

 

SAP Community Updates   

  • What's New:  https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/bg-p/whats-new  
  • Feedback List:  https://community.sap.com/t5/community-corner-feedback-list/idb-p/Coffee-Corneridea-board 
  • Pilot on Widget Removal Frame:  https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/white-space-begone-new-pilot-removes-widgets-column-from-blog-posts/ba-p/14191534  
  • Badges for Kudos:  https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/thumbs-up-for-the-new-kudos-received-progression-badges/ba-p/14193157  
  • Badges for Q&A:  https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/bringing-back-badges-to-reward-q-amp-a-experts/ba-p/14182870  
  • Event Filtering and Dark Mode:  https://community.sap.com/t5/what-s-new/new-features-dark-mode-beta-and-events-listings/ba-p/14191070   

 

ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations 

  • ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/abap-test-cockpit-atc-recommendations-for-governance-of-clean-core-abap/ba-p/14186130 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 SAP BTP ABAP Environment, release 2508 

1:38 SAP Open Source Webinar on Gardener 

2:34 Garden Update - SAP Community   

3:44 SAP Community Updates 

7:07 ABAP test cockpit 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro]This is the SAP Developer News for August the 28th, 2025.

[Rich]Hey friends, Rich Hallman here. I hope everyone is doing well. I'm now fully rusted from the Latin American Code Jam Roadshow. We had a great time and I'm really looking forward to seeing my new friends again soon. But for now, I want to take a minute and let you all know about the latest SAP BTP ABAP environment release, 2508, which just dropped last week. Nora Klemp from ABAP Product Management has posted a blog post outlining all of the new ABAP awesomeness for all of us to explore. ABAP Development Tools got a few updates, including behavior definitions for CDS table entities, a debugger comparison tool for internal tables, as well as other cool stuff. CDS got a new hierarchy generation wizard, which derives potential hierarchy nodes and guides you through the creation process. Fiori got some updates as well, including multi-dimensional reporting and multi-report applications. There are many more updates around business events, integration, reuse services, and much, much more. So check out Nora's blog post today for more information. Hope everyone is doing well, and I'll see you next time, friends. Bye for now.

[DJ]We wanted to just let you know about an upcoming SAP open source webinar on Gartner. Now, Gardner is SAP's open source solution for managing Kubernetes clusters at scale. And the project is now governed under the Neo-Nephos Foundation, which is part of the Linux Foundation Europe. Now, this is a move that really strengthens its long-term sustainability and aligns it with the EU's important projects of common European interest in the cloud infrastructure and services area. that's ipceicis the webinar is on the 24th of september open to all and we'll cover gardeners features see some recent developments and there'll also be some live demos the link to the webinar registration is in the description

[Tom]hi i'm coming to you here from my home garden building on the segment from DJ on Gardener. By home garden, though, I seem to have a problem. I can't get Kubernetes clusters to grow. But in all seriousness, bridging between the segment on Gardener, the open source project, and home gardening, I wanted to point you to a blog post on the SAP community by Marion Weiss sharing his home garden. Now, this isn't the normal SAP developer news segment where we talk about the latest in SAP tech trends. But it's still important because part of our efforts to reinvigorate the SAP community is bring more personality back to the community. So it's great to see Marion sharing his home garden. And we hope to do more initiatives like this and support them where we connect with one another, not just on technical topics, but other things of interest in our lives.

[Josh]Hey, everybody. Mr. Bluebeard, Josh Bentley. I am here as a community advocate to tell you we've been doing a lot of stuff in the community. So as you go through and look at the What's New section of the community, you can see updates and read about them. Jerry Janda even has put out the newsletter recently that he used to publish that actually tries to collate and make you aware of these things. So make sure you subscribe to that newsletter or check out this section of what's new on the SAP community. To that end, I think there's several updates that have been put in place from the actual feedback board that we launched. So if you go to the feedback list and you get involved in that discussion, this is where some of the changes are coming from. So please request more things be added here, dialogue about the things that are on that list. And that's how some of these improvements come to be. and then they make it into the what's new section a recent update that we did that's going to be a pilot until september 23rd is taking away the frames from the side of a blog post where we have a widget and we're going to remove that widget in that side frame and give you a little less white space and more uh content area to read your blog post so check that out see if you like it better let us know and in the blog post in Jerry you can see the compare and contrast of the two pictures that show you what it looks like with it and without it so that's one update that want to make you aware of another is giving more people badges we know you like getting badges in the sap community if you submit an answer or a post that gets a lot of thumbs up those kudos thumbs up likes they're going to give you badges now based on how many kudos that you get for your post so Jerry even references do you want to find out if you're a member of the 500 kudo club well there's a way to check that in the instructions that he post here in this blog post and also you could have a one, a 50, 100, 200, 500 likes, depending on how many people click that they like your post. So great gamification badges that are being awarded for that. And also we really want you to be active and give us good answers in the SAP community. And if you get a lot of accepted answers, we're going to recognize that. And so you're going to see that you are going to get retroactive likes and retroactive accepted answer badges assigned to your profile. So if You've got a lot of accepted answers and a lot of likes. You're going to get those badges assigned to your profile. So another thing, there's so much great information coming out about the community, is that we've actually gone through and we said, hey, it's hard to filter lists for events, and let's try to improve that. So we're adding geographic filtering, and we're also adding the ability to filter lists based on SAP managed tags and a few other features that people have asked for to be able to sort the events that are happening and make sure they don't miss something that they want to attend. so check that out as well as the final note in here which is about dark mode for those who want to actually switch and flip back and forth between dark mode and light mode we are turning on dark mode to the SAP community so if you'd like to compare and contrast that no pun intended but if you'd like to look at the contrasting look of dark mode check that out and you know what people sometimes call me papa smurf and i say that papa smurf had a white beard and blue skin so i'm dark mode papa smurf or maybe i'm light load papa smurf i'm not sure anyway check out dark mode let us know what you think there's lots of information lots of blog posts from Jerry I thank him so much for all the great writing he's been doing and putting out these updates and i hope that you enjoy your sap community it's here for you and we're listening thank you

[Mamikee]if you want to keep your systems clean and future ready it's all about using the ABAP test cockpit or ATC as a governance tool to support the Clean Core approach. The blog post by Olga shares how ATC can help enforce Clean Core principles, things like catching modifications that shouldn't be there, plugging non-release APIs, and making sure your extensions are safe when it comes time to upgrade. Now you can try out the new ATC checks for Clean Core to reduce the number of findings in your classic ABAP development and focus your adaption efforts on real technical depth. If you're building in the ABAP cloud world and want to stay ahead of the curve, this is definitely worth a read. Check the description below for the full blog post.

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Site Improvements, New Badges, and Hot Content
entry.content:
If you’re a What’s New regular, you know we’ve been busy since our last newsletter edition on August 15. We’ve launched new progression badge sets (with more coming in September), made several site improvements, and announced a redesign pilot for blog posts.

If you missed those updates, we summarize them for your convenience below. We also highlight popular blog posts from SAP and non-SAP members, introduce new groups and topic pages, and cover upcoming events.

Read on to learn more!

 

Featured Content

 

ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

SAP’s @OlgaDolinskaja gives a breakdown of new clean-core extensibility guidance and explains how the ABAP extensibility guide has been updated with guidelines that align with and support the clean-core level concept for the classification of custom extensions. You won’t want to miss this post and its lively thread! 

Read the blog post

 

Introducing the New AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

@Punith_Oswal, one of our SAP Champions, has a question for you: Have you ever wished that your iFlow could talk to ChatGPT? If you answered yes, you’ll want to take some time out of your day to read this post. And if you answered no, I still feel pretty positive you’ll enjoy this contribution.

Read the blog post

 

New Series: SAP UX Q3/2025 Updates

A new series from SAP’s @ThomasReiss provides an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering the whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, and SAP SuccessFactors, as well as detailing innovations in SAP’s UI technologies for building great UX.

Start with the first post, which contains links to the entire series

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model with Local App Previews

I’m happy to see our SAP Champions have been so active with their blogging this month! @MioYasutake has written a short blog post detailing experiences while trying out virtual endpoints with SAP Cloud Application Programming Model with Node.js. The post covers findings while testing local previews.

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

Badges, Badges, and More Badges!

Long-time SAP Community members may remember the days when they could earn sets of badges for ongoing positive contributions. Well, we’ve brought these progression badges back! This week, we rolled out four new badges based on the number of kudos received. Last week we assigned badges for providing solutions to questions. And there are more badges coming in the weeks ahead. With these badges, we’re once again recognizing active members and encouraging everyone to make our community a better place by participating more frequently. Make sure to subscribe to What’s New so you won’t miss more badge announcements next month!

 

New Features: Dark Mode (Beta) and Events Listings

A beta version of dark mode is available for SAP Community, and our events listings now include additional filtering options that make it easier for you to find activities of interest to you. You can learn more about these two new features in this post. Experiment with dark mode/light mode to see which presentation works best for you, and try out the various new event filters to find educational and social get-togethers in your area that appeal to you.

 

Your Feedback Wanted for New Design Pilot

We’re currently running a pilot to test a new layout for blog posts that removes widgets and white space from the right column – based on a feature request from members who asked us to improve the readability of these pages. You can learn more about this pilot in this post, and we’re inviting members to share their opinions in the comments there. The pilot concludes on Tuesday, September 23, so please leave your input there before then.

 

New Location Groups Now Available

We’ve launched (or renamed) three location groups. Our Brazilian members continue to expand our groups in the Americas – with the recent addition of Joinville. Over in the Europe section, the former ’s-Hertogenbosch group has switched its name to The Netherlands to accommodate more members in that country. Elsewhere in Europe, we’ve introduced the Düsseldorf-Köln group to bring together members from those cities. If you’re from one of these areas, you’ll want to join the corresponding group so you can connect with members close to you.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Meet SAP TechEd Community Speaker Marla Alschweiki

@TammyPowlas, part of our SAP Mentors program, has referred to the upcoming SAP TechEd event as a family reunion, and so it’s no surprise she’s showing familial-type support for another SAP Mentor, @Marla-Schwaiki (whom we mentioned in the last edition of SAP Community Voice). In this post, Tammy explains why you should attend Marla’s community talk in Berlin. We love seeing members supporting members, so if you’re planning to attend SAP TechEd, please make sure to include Marla’s session in your schedule.

 

Find Meetup Events in Your Region

In the last two SAP Community Voice newsletters, we’ve focused on SAP CodeJam events, but as explained earlier in this edition, our events listings have been expanded to include filters for finding a variety of local activities. Therefore, I’d like to use this edition to draw attention to meetups (also known as SAP Stammtisch events in Germany) in September. Next month, you can socialize with members in Wien (Austria), Gurugram (India), Casablanca (Morocco), Dortmund (Germany), Cyprus (Greece), Brussels (Belgium), Warsaw (Poland), Lingen (Germany), Bamberg (Germany), Hamburg (Germany), Porto (Portugal), Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil), and Luzern (Switzerland). You can find a full list of events here. Make sure to register for an event near you!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Londrina 2025: Paraguay sigue expandiendo fronteras
entry.content:
¡Una nueva aventura de aprendizaje llegó a su fin! El pasado fin de semana tuvimos el privilegio de participar en el SAP Inside Track Londrina 2025, confirmando una vez más que la comunidad SAP brasileña tiene mucho que enseñarnos y que Paraguay está cada vez más presente en estos espacios de conocimiento.

Una agenda de lujo

El evento nos sorprendió con una selección de temas súper actuales y relevantes para el mercado:

  • SAP BTP Descomplicado - Thiago Toma y Adriano Toma nos mostraron cómo posicionarse estratégicamente en el mercado actual
  • SAP QM Quality Management en S/4 HANA - Valdevair Bezerra compartió las innovaciones más importantes para la industria
  • S/4 Public Cloud: Implementación ágil y diferenciada - Jean Baena y Clariana Narcizo demostraron las ventajas de esta modalidad
  • Simplificando BTP Integration Suite - Danilo Oliveira nos ayudó a entender mejor esta poderosa herramienta
  • APIs Funcionales - Kessia Salazar explicó su aplicación práctica
  • Seguridad en Aplicaciones/Servicios en BTP en tiempos de IA: historia y evolución - Por José Sequeira @jose_sequeira 

Gratitud especial

Un reconocimiento muy especial para Jean Tiago Baena @Jean_Chess_IT por recibirnos con tanta calidez y hacer que nos sintiéramos como en casa. Su hospitalidad y la de todo el equipo organizador fueron excepcionales.

El factor humano: lo que realmente importa

Más allá de las presentaciones técnicas, lo que más valor aporta en estos eventos son las conversaciones durante los breaks, esos momentos de networking genuino donde se forjan relaciones que trascienden lo profesional. La comunidad SAP brasileña nos sigue demostrando su generosidad para compartir conocimiento.

Paraguay en el mapa SAP

Cada participación en estos eventos SIT nos da más experiencia y motivación para seguir construyendo nuestra propia comunidad. Estamos absorbiendo las mejores prácticas y adaptándolas a nuestra realidad paraguaya.

Rumbo a SIT Paraguay 2025

Con cada evento que visitamos, se fortalece más nuestra visión de realizar el primer SIT Paraguay en noviembre. Queremos que nuestros colegas locales tengan acceso a este mismo nivel de contenido y networking, sin necesidad de viajar.

¡Gracias Londrina por recibirnos tan bien! Nos vemos pronto en el próximo SIT, y esperamos que pronto sea en Paraguay.

Si eres profesional SAP en Paraguay, ¡únete a nuestra comunidad! Síguenos en LinkedIn para estar al tanto de nuestros próximos encuentros.

SAP Community  SAP Inside Track

entry.title: Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙 ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‌

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Mission

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample mission (just a warm-up, no points will be earned).

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

26SAP Community

Use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the previous column and find the 6-digit ASCII code for the color of the text.

 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits, in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

👉Post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase) -- you won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example mission, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) mission

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

👉To be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

‌ When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions:

 

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25
26 To be released Sept. 29
34 To be released Sept. 29
42 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 2
54 To be released Oct. 6
66 To be released Oct. 6
76 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 9
86 To be released Oct. 13
91 To be released Oct. 13
10None (directly) Watch the Developer News of Oct. 16

Good luck!

😸

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025: A Technical Consultant's Journey Through Innovation, AI Use cases
entry.content:
As I sit down to consider the amazing experience of SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025, which was conducted on August 2nd at the grand St. Xavier's University in New Town, I'm blessed to have such a huge sense of appreciation for the chance to have been included in such a motivating community event. Not only did I come as an avid SAP technical consultant but also as a coordinating volunteer for Track 2, and this provided me with an unrivalled insight into both the organizational expertise and technical expertise that made this event so exceptional.

The Perfect Setting for Innovation
St. Xavier's University Kolkata offered the perfect setting for our community meet. 

The commitment of the university to excellence was reflected in each and every aspect, from the state-of-the-art conference rooms to the stable network infrastructure underpinning our live demos and interactive sessions. Having been to many technical conferences, I can safely say that the venue contributed significantly to delivering the quality experience that SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 provided.

Track 2: Leading the Charge in Enterprise Transformation
Since I was the coordinating volunteer for Track 2, I had the privilege of collaborating very closely with some of the greatest minds in the SAP universe. Our track covered intelligent enterprise transformation and had the most innovative topics that are revolutionizing the way companies do business today.

RISE with SAP: Charting the Path to Intelligence
The day started with Debashis Majumder's engaging session on "RISE with SAP: Your Path to the Intelligent Enterprise". This session was all the more insightful because it highlighted how RISE with SAP is an end-to-end transformation package that brings together SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the SAP Business Technology Platform, and managed services to deliver an end-to-end digital transformation solution.

What I was most impressed by in this session was the way that RISE with SAP covers the entire range of enterprise requirements - from managed services and cloud infrastructure to business transformation as a service, as well as emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and robotic process automation. As a technical consultant, I appreciated the conversation regarding the subscription model and the cost-effectiveness. This is especially important for the clients that I deal with who are looking at cloud migration strategies.

Joule Studio: Democratization of AI Agent Development
Koushik Goon's "What is Joule Studio and how it works?" presentation was completely captivating. Joule Studio, under SAP Build, is a game-changer in how we work with AI-powered business automation. The ability to design and deploy custom Joule agents and skills with easy-to-use drag-and-drop simplicity presents huge opportunities for companies to make AI solutions customized to their requirements.

The showcase of how developers can create AI agents that solve goal-oriented, complex business situations using dynamic planning and reasoning was impressive. The SAP and third-party application integration ensures the AI agents integrate well across various technology landscapes, a key requirement in the heterogeneous environments most companies use today.

Business AI and S/4HANA Integration
Sangeeta Majumder's presentation on "Business AI Use Cases with S/4HANA and SAP's AI Suite" offered real-world examples of how artificial intelligence is being integrated into central business processes. The session touched on real-world applications across business functions, from procurement optimization to financial reporting, illustrating quantifiable business value.

IBM's GenAI Assets and Platform Accelerators
The shared session between Aditi Chatterjee and Avijit Dhar on "Overview of IBM's Latest GenAI Assets and Process Accelerators on the IBM-SAP Platform" brought out the strategic significance of partner ecosystems in providing end-to-end AI solutions. Their observations about how IBM's generative AI assets are bundled with SAP platforms for speeding up business processes were especially insightful to understanding the wider AI picture beyond SAP's native capabilities.

Intelligent Invoicing Revolution
Arit Basu's talk on "Intelligent Invoicing using SAP Business Network" highlighted the real-world application of AI to daily business practices. The Intelligent Invoice Conversion functionality, leveraging Document Information Extraction (DOX) technology, to convert PDF and image-based invoice files into structured SAP Business Network invoices automatically, is a major step in accounts payable automation.

I was amazed by the demonstration of how machine learning algorithms automatically extract and map invoice information, with an easy-to-use interface for suppliers to create annotation rules for complicated invoice data. This product solves a genuine pain point that most of my customers experience in their procure-to-pay processes.

Next-Generation Field Mobility
The last Track 2 session, "Next-Gen Field Mobility: What's New in SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505" by Abhishek Chatterjee, discussed the transformation of mobile enterprise apps. The emphasis on growing field service functions with enhanced mobility solutions was a big hit with many of the participants who have asset-heavy businesses.

Networking: The Heart of Community Building
One of the greatest assets of SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 was the awesome networking opportunity it offered. As noted in numerous community forums, networking for SAP technical consultants is not merely a matter of swapping business cards - it's about creating enduring professional relationships that enable knowledge sharing, career growth, and access to out-of-the-way opportunities.

Throughout the event, I engaged in substantive discussions with:

Other ABAP colleagues who exchanged innovative coding methods and debugging approaches

S/4HANA transformation project peers working on similar functional consulting projects

Industry specialists who shared their vision on upcoming trends and best practices

Community leaders leading different SAP user groups in India

The afternoon fireside chat with community contributors was most informative, with participants from AWS User Group Kolkata, Kolkata WordPress Community, Databricks Community India, and SAP Community Kolkata. This inter-community collaboration session, led by Dipanwita Dutta, highlighted the need to bridge different technology communities to promote innovation and learning.

Keynote Insights and Industry Perspectives
The keynote sessions on the first day of the event established a strong tone for the whole event. SAP Community Senior Director Josh "Bluebeard" Bentley's speech highlighted the importance of community-based learning and collaboration in the SAP community. His perspectives on how the international SAP community keeps adapting and evolving with emerging technologies were inspiring and thought-provoking.

Srini Gottimukkula's keynote provided valuable industry perspectives on the current state and future direction of SAP technologies. The emphasis on intelligent enterprises and the role of AI-driven transformation aligned perfectly with the themes explored throughout our track sessions.

The welcome address by Reverend Dr. John Felix Raj, the Honourable Vice Chancellor of St. Xavier's University, beautifully captured the spirit of academic excellence and community collaboration that characterized the entire event.

Panel Discussions: Multiple Insights on Digital Transformation
The two panel sessions offered multiple perspectives on hot issues impacting the SAP community:

Panel Session 1 included industry experts such as Pankaj Lal, Prasun Dutta, Debashis Majumdar, Sarmistha Shanyal, and Tilak Kumar Dhar, moderated by Monimoy Kundu. The topics discussed ranged from practical SAP implementation strategy tips to lessons learned from actual projects.

Panel Session 2 represented a coming together of academic and industry viewpoints with speakers consisting of Prof. Amlan Chakrabarti, Dr. Indranil Mitra, Manoj Mishra, Dr. Saptarsi Goswami, Sabyasachi Biswas, and Srini Gottimukkula, moderated by Amitava Nag. The session offered useful insights into the convergence of academic research and industry usage in the SAP space.

Technical Deep Dives Across Multiple Tracks
Though I was mainly busy coordinating Track 2, I got a chance to visit sessions on other tracks during the break times:

Track 1 had extensive sessions on supply chain transformation using AI-driven intelligence, next-gen warehouse operations, and cloud ALM roadshow presentations. The focus on real-world applications and live demos made these sessions very useful.

Track 3 explored in-depth generative AI embedding within business strategy, SAP BTP highlights from the view of a Basis consultant, and best practices for SAP S/4HANA transformation. The session on "Leveraging SAP Conversational & Generative AI: Bengali Code Bot" was also very innovative and highlighted how AI can be localized for local needs.

Track 4 was data engineering and analytics, with sessions on Databricks, AWS and SAP integration, and foundation for Gen AI with SAP. These sessions gave a proper understanding of the overall ecosystem of technologies that go along with SAP solutions.

Key Takeaways for Technical Consultants
Being a SAP technical consultant, some key learnings that will have a direct effect on my work are:

1. AI Integration is Accelerating
The prolonged emphasis on Joule, AI agents, and intelligent automation in several sessions undoubtedly demonstrates that the integration of AI is no longer a consideration for the future - it's an existing imperative. Technical consultants must acquire skills in AI-powered SAP solutions to stay relevant.

2. Cloud-First Mindset is Mandatory
RISE with SAP and the other cloud-focused sessions validated that the sector has moved irrevocably towards cloud-first approaches. Cloud deployment models, migration approaches, and hybrid architectures are essential knowledge areas for technical consultants.

3. Low-Code/No-Code Platforms are Mainstream
The exhibition of Joule Studio's drag-and-drop feature and equivalent platforms in other sessions demonstrated that low-code development is going mainstream. Technical consultants must adopt these platforms alongside core development expertise.

4. Community Involvement Spur Learning
The networking and information exchange that were experienced during the event proved the tremendous benefit of an engaged community. Bi-weekly exposure to the SAP Community Network, local user communities, and events such as SAP Inside Track is crucial for career development.

Organizational Excellence Behind the Scenes
As a coordinating volunteer, I developed profound respect for the colossal effort that went into making this event happen. The SAP Inside Track Kolkata team showcased outstanding professionalism in handling:

Multi-track coordination with smooth transitions among sessions

The success of the event is a testament to the tireless organizers and volunteers who spent hundreds of hours on planning and execution. The SAP Community Network principles of knowledge sharing, collaboration, and support were manifested in every step of the event.

Looking Forward: The Future of SAP Community Events
SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 has established a new standard for community events in the region. The confluence of leading-edge technical content, industry expert views, hands-on demonstrations, and substantive networking opportunities provided an experience that will leave its mark on all participants.

The event proved that the Kolkata SAP community is not only consuming knowledge from the world but actively taking part in the worldwide SAP universe. The variety of speakers, the technical depth of conversations, and the quality of questions asked by participants reflected the maturity and professionalism of the local SAP community.

Conclusion: A Day That Transformed Perspectives
SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 was not just a conference - it was a celebration of learning, innovation, and community. Having worked in the SAP ecosystem for a few years now, I departed from the event rejuvenated with the potential that awaits us.

The technical learnings from sessions on AI, cloud transition, and intelligent automation will impact my client work directly. The working relationships forged during the day are already starting to bear collaborative opportunities. Above all, the feeling of community and commonality that pervaded the event was the reminder of why I decided to work in the SAP ecosystem.

To fellow SAP technical consultants who might be thinking of attending future SAP Inside Track events, I do not say enough good things about them. They offer a unique chance to:

Get up to date on the latest SAP technologies and industry trends

Meet peers, experts, and potential collaborators

Give back to the community through knowledge sharing and mentoring

Boost your professional image and career opportunities

Get hands-on experience with innovative solutions and best practices

The success of the SAP community is based on its collaborative nature and shared success. Examples such as SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2025 encapsulate these principles to perfection, generating environments where ideas are exchanged freely, bonds are forged, and innovation takes root.

I'm already counting down to SAP Inside Track Kolkata 2026 and the chance to extend this journey of discovery, sharing, and community building. Until that time, I invite all members of the SAP community to remain connected, keep up the learning, and keep adding to that shared knowledge that makes our ecosystem so rich and valuable.

#SAPInsideTrack #SAPCommunity #KolkataSAP #DigitalTransformation #RISEwithSAP #JouleStudio #SAPTechnicalnsultant #AIInBusiness #CloudTransformation

Heartfelt appreciation to the dream team who made every session, every connection, and every moment absolutely count!
