entry.title: SAP CodeJam Roadshow LATAM 2025 - recap
entry.content:
And that's a wrap..... Together with @josh_bentley, @RichHeilman, @thomas_jung, @SavioMarques, @jessicademarchi and @caiograbalos, we did a few SAP CodeJams in Latin America - four different cities (São Paulo 🇧🇷, Lima 🇵🇪, Mexico City 🇲🇽 and Bogota 🇨🇴), various meetups and even joined the SAP Inside Track in São Paulo. As part of the roadshow, we run the Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and ABAP Cloud & ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model CodeJams. It is always great to meet community members where they are and learn about the challenges they face in the different project and how SAP products enable them to tackle these.

 

This is the 2nd roadshow we've done in the region, and what a great experience it was. It was great to meet in person many SAP community members that I've interacted with online in the past. As well as seeing some familiar faces in the locations that we visited in the 1st LATAM roadshow.

São Paulo 🇧🇷

@josh_bentley already share a recap of the events in Brazil and the first event in Peru.... so go ahead and check out all the photos he is sharing in the blog post - https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-codejam-discussions/sap-codejam-roadshow-latam-2025-the-first-half-recap-being-present-is-about/td-p/14173987 

Lima 🇵🇪

This is the first time we've done CodeJams in Lima, hosted at the SAP office. It was great to meet the local community and lovely to enjoy some of the local cuisine and coffee :-). Thanks to everyone who joined, even though there was a holiday right in the middle of the week #PeruEsClave.

 

 

 

 

 

Mexico City 🇲🇽

Two amazing events hosted at the IBM offices in Mexico City. I got the opportunity to meet SAP Champions - @Sandra_Solis and @MariettaLopez, whom I've interacted with in the past but never before met in person. Also, Devtoberfest winners - @Sandra_Solis and @eamarce23. Thanks to IBM for hosting, looking forward to more events in Mexico :-). The day after the CodeJams we also had the opportunity to visit the Museo Nacional de Antropologia time and get some time to learn about the different Mexican indigenous cultures.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


 

 

 

 

 

Bogota 🇨🇴

Last city part of the 2nd LATAM CodeJam roadshow. The day before the events, there was some time to explore the city a bit and visit the Museo Botero, as well as the Casa de Moneda. The events took place @ the SAP office in Bogota. It was great to catch up with various previous CodeJam attendees, as well as meet some more community members. Special mention to the large crew who joined the CodeJams from Globant (Bogota and Cali).... next time we will organise the event at the Globant office haha

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


 


 

Personally, I always feel energised after connecting with the large Latin American SAP community and I know that it is also a great experience for the other advocates that have joined the roadshows. I'm already looking forward to next year and doing more CodeJams in the region.

entry.title: Trends in B2B Commerce Webcast
entry.content:
Привіт, Community!

Зовсім скоро відбудеться вебкаст про майбутнє B2B-комерції. Подія базується на свіжому дослідженні 2025 State of B2B eCommerce Report від Master B2B.

📅У вівторок, 9 вересня 2025 року о 13.00, запрошуємо на онлайн-сесію «Тренди B2B-комерції 2025: як подолати бар’єри на шляху до розвитку». Її проведе Меганн Йорк, Global Head of Product Marketing в SAP Commerce Cloud, а спеціальним гостем стане наш клієнт — компанія Arauco.

Поговоримо про виклики, з якими стикається B2B-комерція сьогодні: організаційну складність, потребу в цифровому лідерстві та інші фактори, що часто гальмують трансформацію. Ми покажемо, як бізнеси успішно поєднують технології, таланти та партнерство, щоб рухатися вперед. Ви отримаєте конкретні ідеї та стратегії, які допоможуть керувати складними процесами й ефективно використовувати цифрові інструменти для досягнення цілей.

Реєструйтеся за посиланням.

entry.title: Give a Kudo, Get a Badge
entry.content:
Last week, we began to assign badges based on the number of kudos a member received. But what about the members who kindly grant kudos? Don’t they deserve some recognition, too?

We think so, and that’s why, starting tomorrow (Wednesday, September 3), we’re launching our latest progression set – based on kudos given.

As with the other badges that we recently rolled out, this set contains five badges, the first of which has been available since the launch of our current platform last year. The rest are new. You make your way through the set as your activity meets the associated criteria. With these badges, you’ll acquire the second one after giving 30 kudos, the third after 75, the fourth after 200, and the fifth and final after 500.

That’s a whole lot of kudos clicked!

Badges will start appearing in people’s “My content” area tomorrow – and we’ll require a few hours to assign them all. Since we’ll once again award them retroactively, you can already anticipate what you’ll attain (if anything) by looking at your accrued activity. How? Here’s a refresher.

After logging in, select “My content” from the dropdown in the upper right.

Once you’ve navigated to your “My content” page, look for the gray box at the top. This area contains several stats, including “Kudos given.” As an example, I’m once again turning to my anonymous friend (who was the source of my screenshots for previous posts).

With more than 1,700 kudos given, he’ll complete the set during tomorrow’s rollout (having surpassed the threshold for all of the new badges…and then some!).

That’s some serious gold-medal kudo judo!

Now if you were so inclined, you could go give hundreds of kudos right now (although your finger might get sore from clicking all those thumbs), ensuring that you also complete the set tomorrow. But your kudos carry way more weight when you dole them out deservingly. Why give them away randomly when you can make another member’s day by delivering a kudo that sincerely indicates that you read and appreciated his or her content?

As someone who writes frequently for SAP Community, I can attest to the warm and fuzzy feeling that comes from a kudo. Clicking that thumb is such a simple act, yet its impact is undeniable for the recipient. It sends the message: “I like what you did. Thank you.” For that reason, I’m glad to see that our community’s cool kudo givers can earn rewards for their generosity.

If you expect to gain one or more “kudos given” badges tomorrow, then let me give you a big thumbs up in advance. Also, as a reminder: If you don’t see your badges by Thursday, September 4, please log out and in again. And if you haven’t racked up the necessary numbers yet for the full set, don’t worry. You can always win the badges later by reading and reacting to contributions throughout the community.  

In conclusion: Keep the thumbing coming for the content that you like, and make sure to check back next week. We plan to unveil more progression badge sets in September, and we’ll announce them weekly right here in What’s New. In the meantime, remain an active, positive member, and you may find yourself surprised with even more badges this month.

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration – Simplifying Error Handling with a Generic Retry iFlow for Kafka
entry.content:
Traditional Retry Handling in SAP Cloud Integration

Apache Kafka is an open-source distributed event streaming platform used for building real-time data pipelines and applications. It allows you to publish, store, and process streams of records in a fault-tolerant and highly scalable way. It is often used for high-throughput, low-latency messaging between systems.

In enterprise-level integration cases, temporary failures are an unfortunate reality — particularly in the context of asynchronous messaging systems such as Apache Kafka. Ensuring these momentary glitches do not lead to data loss or message failure is essential.

In SAP Cloud Integration (CI) iFlows with Kafka, retries are traditionally handled by leveraging Kafka consumer offset management, which allows unprocessed messages to be redelivered. While this ensures reliable message delivery in case of temporary errors, it also introduces challenges such as potential message duplication, out-of-order processing, and difficulty in distinguishing between transient and permanent errors. These factors can complicate error handling and increase the complexity of downstream processing.

Introducing the Retry Mechanism iFlow for Kafka

This blog presents a reusable Retry Mechanism iFlow designed specifically for Kafka as the source. It includes configurable retry logic, failure escalation by JIRA ticket, exponential wait time, and dead-letter handling using Apache Kafka — all packaged into a generic integration flow you can insert into numerous pipelines.

Key Features

  •   Generic & Reusable: To be used across iFlows where Kafka is the sender.
  •   Dynamic Configuration:
  1. Retry Count
  2. Retry Interval
  3. Kafka Original & DMQ Topic
  •   Optional JIRA ticket creation: For persistent failures.
  •   Dead Message Queue (DMQ) Handling: Failed messages are routed to a Kafka topic for traceability.

Configurable Parameters (passed via headers from source iFlow)

Parameter

Description

Retry Interval (in seconds)

Wait time before each retry attempt.

Maximum Retry Attempts

Number of times a message retry is attempted.

Kafka Original Topic (Header)

Destination topic for reprocessing.

DMQ Topic (Header)

Topic for persistently failed messages.

Flow Diagram

 

Integration Flow

Below is a sample Integration Flow created to handle retries selectively for connectivity and interface errors.

 

Flow Logic Explained

1 Start

  • Triggered via Process Direct Adapter when an error occurs in the main iFlow.
  • Retry? Checks if the message has exceeded maximum retries.
    • Yes → Retry sequence.
    • No → DMQ + Escalation flow.

NOTE:
The expression retryCount[last] accesses the last element of the retryCount header array to ensure the latest retry attempt is evaluated during routing.

Retry Sequence

  • Sleep
    Groovy script reads waitTime and retryCount headers, calculates an exponential backoff delay (waitTime^retryCount), sleeps for that duration in milliseconds, and sets the new waitTime header accordingly. It preserves the original message body throughout the process.
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get all headers
    Map<String, Object> headers = message.getHeaders()

    // --- Extract last value from 'waitTime' header ---
    def waitTimeHeader = headers.get("waitTime")
    Integer waitTime = 1 // Default fallback

    if (waitTimeHeader instanceof List || waitTimeHeader?.getClass()?.isArray()) {
        def lastValue = waitTimeHeader[-1]
        waitTime = lastValue?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 1
    } else if (waitTimeHeader != null) {
        waitTime = waitTimeHeader?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 1
    }

    // --- Extract last value from 'retryCount' header ---
    def retryCountHeader = headers.get("retryCount")
    Integer retryCount = 1 // Default fallback

    if (retryCountHeader instanceof List || retryCountHeader?.getClass()?.isArray()) {
        def lastValue = retryCountHeader[-1]
        retryCount = lastValue?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 1
    } else if (retryCountHeader != null) {
        retryCount = retryCountHeader?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 1
    }

    // --- Calculate exponential backoff ---
    Integer sleepTimeInSeconds = Math.pow(waitTime, retryCount) as Integer
    Integer sleepTimeInMillis = sleepTimeInSeconds * 1000

    // Set new header
    message.setHeader("waitTime", sleepTimeInSeconds)

    // Preserve original body and sleep
    def body = message.getBody()
    sleep(sleepTimeInMillis)

    message.setBody(body)
    return message
}
  • Increment Retry Counter
    This Groovy script reads the retryCount header (handling both single values and arrays), retrieves the last value, increments it by 1, and sets it back in the message header. It ensures retry tracking is correctly updated for each attempt.
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get all headers
    Map<String, Object> headers = message.getHeaders()

    // Extract retryCount header
    def retryCountHeader = headers.get("retryCount")
    Integer currentCount = 0 // Default fallback

    // If retryCount is an array or list, get the last value
    if (retryCountHeader instanceof List || retryCountHeader?.getClass()?.isArray()) {
        def lastValue = retryCountHeader[-1]
        currentCount = lastValue?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 0
    } else if (retryCountHeader != null) {
        // Handle as single value
        currentCount = retryCountHeader?.toString()?.toInteger() ?: 0
    }

    // Increment the counter
    currentCount += 1

    // Set the updated value back to the header
    message.setHeader("retryCount", currentCount)

    return message
}
​
  • Restore Original Payload
    Ensures original data is intact for reprocessing.
  • Resend to Kafka Topic
    Message is pushed back to the original Kafka topic.

Failure Handling & Escalation

  • Send to DMQ
    Routes the message to a Dead Message Queue Topic on Kafka for monitoring or auditing. Similar configuration as above, change the Topic name accordingly.
  • JIRA Ticket creation?
    Based on user’s configuration in main iflow, determines if a JIRA ticket can be created or not.Construct Body
    Adds message context, failure reason, and other metadata in a body.
  • Creates JIRA Ticket
    Sends alert to support or integration teams. In this blog I am not covering all Jira configurations, for more information on the this please go through Jira Adapter for SAP Integration Suite.

           Jira Adapter Response

           Jira Ticket

  • Escalation End
    Ends process after notification or after DMQ routing if alerts are disabled. 

Integration Points

  • Apache Kafka: As the core message broker retry target and DMQ for message persistence.
  • JIRA Adapter: For failure escalation and ticket creation.

Split-in-iFlow Pattern: When Kafka Isn’t the Source

In scenarios where the source adapter is not Kafka (e.g., HTTP, IDoc, SFTP), you can still use the Retry Mechanism by applying a split-iFlow design:

Pattern Overview

IFlow

Role

iFlow 1: Sender Adapter → Kafka

Ingest source data, sends to Kafka (Original Topic), sets required headers.

iFlow 2: Kafka → Processing

Handles mapping, transformation, and receiver logic.

Error Path

On failure, calls Retry Mechanism iFlow (via Process Direct).

Retry Cycle

Retry iFlow manages reprocessing or escalation based on logic.

 

This architecture maintains loose coupling, dynamic routing, and centralized error handling across varied protocols and business cases.

Why This Matters

  • Reduces custom retry logic across iFlows.
  • Centralizes failure handling and monitoring.
  • Makes Kafka-based processing more robust and recoverable.
  • Aligns with event-driven architecture best practices.

Final Thoughts

The Retry Mechanism iFlow is a foundational building block for resilient Kafka integrations in SAP Cloud Integration. Whether you’re integrating external systems, APIs, or internal processes — having a centralized, configurable retry logic ensures smoother operations and reduces manual interventions.

References

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/cloud-integration-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-kafka-adapter/ba-p/13495070
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/optimized-error-management-and-retry-strategy-with-kafka-on-sap-cloud/ba-p/13810790
  • https://medium.com/@lahirurajapakshe.stack/apache-kafka-retry-mechanism-documentation-4cf67f80d6f7
